post_title: A solar cell you can bend and soak in water
post_content:
The development of waterproof and flexible organic photovoltaic (OPV) films opens up new possibilities for integrating solar cells into wearable electronics. Researchers from the RIKEN Center for Emergent Matter Science and collaborators have successfully created a waterproof OPV film that can withstand exposure to water, stretching, and even washing machine cycles without compromising its performance.

Traditional OPV films consist of multiple layers, with an active layer responsible for capturing sunlight and converting it into electricity. One of the challenges in creating waterproof OPVs is maintaining flexibility while ensuring water resistance. In this study, scientists addressed this issue by directly depositing the anode layer, a silver electrode, onto the active layers to improve adhesion between the layers.

By subjecting the film to thermal annealing at 85°C for 24 hours, the researchers were able to enhance the film's waterproof properties while maintaining its flexibility. The resulting film, only 3 micrometers thick, exhibited impressive performance even after being immersed in water, stretched underwater, and subjected to a washing machine cycle.

The innovative approach taken by the researchers not only demonstrates the feasibility of creating waterproof and flexible OPVs but also opens up new possibilities for practical applications in wearable devices. By improving the stability of OPVs in various environmental conditions, such as exposure to air, light, and mechanical stress, the researchers aim to further enhance the usability of ultrathin organic solar cells in real-world applications.

This groundbreaking research, published in Nature Communications, paves the way for the development of next-generation wearable electronics that harness the power of solar energy in a durable and versatile form. The potential for integrating solar cells into clothing and other wearable devices holds promise for a future where energy generation and consumption are seamlessly integrated into everyday life.

post_title: New study finds invisible 'human work' allows robots to make deliveries
post_content:
The integration of autonomous delivery robots into our daily lives is a fascinating phenomenon that showcases the intricate dance between technology and human behavior. A recent study conducted by researchers from the University of Nottingham, Linkoping University, and the University of York sheds light on the crucial role that human interactions play in the smooth operation of these delivery robots on the streets.

In cities like Milton Keynes and Northampton in the U.K., delivery robots are becoming a common sight as they navigate the urban landscape to fulfill their delivery tasks. Powered by artificial intelligence and GPS navigation, these robots rely on the cooperation and accommodation of people they encounter along their routes to ensure seamless movement.

The research conducted by the interdisciplinary team involved observing and filming the interactions between delivery robots and various individuals on the streets. What emerged from their study was the subtle yet significant ways in which people modified their behavior to facilitate the robot's progress. From stepping aside to allow the robot to pass to adjusting their walking pace to maintain a safe distance, individuals demonstrated a remarkable adaptability in their interactions with these autonomous entities.

Dr. Stuart Reeves, a key researcher from the University of Nottingham, emphasized the importance of recognizing the role that human presence plays in the successful operation of delivery robots in public spaces. While designers often focus on optimizing routes and programming robots, it is the everyday actions of people on the streets that ultimately determine the robot's ability to navigate effectively without becoming an obstacle itself.

The study, presented at the prestigious ACM/IEEE International Conference on Human-Robot Interaction, highlighted the need for a deeper understanding of how robots and humans coexist in shared environments. By acknowledging and integrating these insights into the design and deployment of robotic technologies, cities and robot designers can create more harmonious and efficient interactions between robots and the public.

As we continue to witness the evolution and expansion of robot technology in public spaces, it is essential to consider the nuanced dynamics at play and leverage this knowledge to enhance the integration of robots into our daily lives. By embracing the symbiotic relationship between humans and robots, we can pave the way for a future where autonomous entities seamlessly navigate our urban landscapes with the support and cooperation of the people they encounter.

post_title: Researchers send data 4.5 million times faster than average broadband
post_content:
Aston University researchers have achieved a groundbreaking milestone in data transmission, sending data at a speed that surpasses home broadband by a staggering 4.5 million times. This remarkable feat, accomplished through an international collaboration, saw data being transferred at an unprecedented rate of 301 terabits per second using a standard optical fiber.

Led by Professor Wladek Forysiak and Dr. Ian Phillips, the team harnessed new wavelength bands that are currently unused in fiber optic systems to achieve this incredible speed. By leveraging optical fibers, which transmit information using light, the researchers were able to push the boundaries of data transmission capabilities beyond what traditional copper cables can handle.

The key to their success lies in the development of innovative devices such as optical amplifiers and optical gain equalizers that allowed access to these untapped wavelength bands. Dr. Phillips, who spearheaded the development of an optical processor at Aston University, explained the significance of their achievement in expanding the spectrum of light used for data transmission.

The utilization of additional spectral bands, namely the E-band and S-band alongside the conventional C and L-bands, marked a significant advancement in optical fiber technology. By increasing the transmission capacity in the backbone network, the researchers anticipate a substantial improvement in connections for end-users, paving the way for faster and more reliable data transmission.

This groundbreaking accomplishment underscores the pivotal role of optical fiber technology in revolutionizing communication networks. By maximizing the available spectrum and optimizing existing fiber networks, the researchers have not only enhanced data transmission capabilities but also contributed to cost-efficiency and sustainability in the long run.

The results of this groundbreaking experiment, published by the Institute of Engineering and Technology, were presented at the European Conference on Optical Communication (ECOC) in October 2023. This significant achievement sets a new benchmark in data transmission capabilities and holds immense promise for meeting the escalating demands for high-speed data in the digital age.

Acknowledging the challenges of selling to government entities, Pelaez shared that Cyvl.ai has found success by partnering with external civil engineering firms. post_title: Ron DeSantis signs bill requiring parental consent for kids to join social media platforms in Florida
post_content:
Florida Governor Ron DeSantis recently approved a bill known as HB 3, which introduces stricter regulations regarding children under 16 using social media. The law prohibits kids under 14 from engaging in social media platforms altogether.

For 14- and 15-year-olds, parental or guardian consent is now mandatory to create or use a social media account. Moreover, the companies operating these platforms must comply with requests to delete such accounts within five business days. Failure to do so could result in significant fines, up to $10,000 per violation. In cases of deliberate or reckless violations, the penalties escalate to $50,000 per incident.

Under this new law, individuals under 14 are barred from creating or accessing social media accounts in Florida. The platforms are required to erase existing accounts along with any associated personal data. While the legislation doesn't specify particular social media platforms, it applies to services featuring elements like infinite scrolling, reaction metrics, live streaming, and auto-play videos. However, email platforms are excluded from these regulations.

This legislation not only impacts the online behavior of children but also implements an age verification requirement for websites or apps containing potentially harmful content for users under 18. For instance, Floridians visiting adult sites must verify their age using a platform on the site or a third-party system. News outlets are exempt from this provision, even if they meet the content threshold.

Privacy concerns arise with the requirement to disclose personal information for age verification. Websites have the option to direct users to an "anonymous age verification" system, where third parties are prohibited from retaining identifying data. Failure to comply with this rule could result in a $50,000 civil penalty per violation.

Earlier this month, DeSantis vetoed a similar bill that would have prohibited teens under 16 from using social media apps without parental consent. NetChoice, a trade association representing social media platforms, has criticized the law as unconstitutional, arguing that it will lead to extensive data collection and compromise privacy and security.

State House Speaker Paul Renner highlighted the need for intervention to protect children from the addictive nature of technology. The law becomes effective on January 1, but it may face legal challenges. Renner anticipates social media companies to file lawsuits immediately, and DeSantis acknowledges potential First Amendment challenges to the law.

post_title: Databricks spent $10M on new DBRX generative AI model, but it can't beat GPT-4
post_content:
If you had $10 million to raise the profile of your major tech company, how would you spend it? Would you go for a Super Bowl ad or an F1 sponsorship? While those are traditional marketing strategies, a more unconventional approach could involve investing in training a generative AI model.

Generative AI models are becoming attention-grabbers in the tech world, serving as funnels to vendors' core products and services. Take, for example, Databricks' latest offering, DBRX. This generative AI model, similar to OpenAI's GPT series and Google's Gemini, is now available on GitHub and the AI dev platform Hugging Face for both research and commercial use. With base (DBRX Base) and fine-tuned (DBRX Instruct) versions, DBRX can process a wide range of topics and languages, including English, French, Spanish, and German.

While Databricks touts DBRX as "open source," similar to models like Meta's Llama 2 and Mistral's offerings, there is ongoing debate about whether these models truly fit the open-source definition. Databricks invested approximately $10 million and two months into training DBRX, claiming that it outperforms existing open-source models on standard benchmarks.

However, accessing and using DBRX can be challenging, especially for non-Databricks customers. Running the model requires high-end hardware, such as servers or PCs with Nvidia H100 GPUs, which can be costly and out of reach for many developers and solopreneurs. While running the model on third-party clouds is an option, the hardware requirements remain steep.

To address these challenges, Databricks offers the Mosaic AI Foundation Model as a managed solution. This product not only runs DBRX but also provides a training stack for fine-tuning the model on custom data. Customers can host DBRX privately using Databricks' Model Serving offering or work with the company to deploy it on their preferred hardware.

DBRX distinguishes itself with its MoE (mixture of experts) architecture, featuring 16 experts compared to the typical eight. This architecture, shared with models like Mistral's and Google's Gemini 1.5 Pro, contributes to DBRX's claimed 2x faster performance compared to Llama 2. While DBRX excels in certain benchmarks, it falls short of OpenAI's GPT-4 in broader applications.

Despite its strengths, DBRX, like other generative AI models, has limitations. It can produce inaccurate responses due to "hallucinating" answers and lacks multimodal capabilities, focusing solely on text processing. The sources of data used to train DBRX remain undisclosed, raising questions about its training data's quality and diversity.

In conclusion, while DBRX represents a significant advancement in generative AI, its accessibility and performance may pose challenges for some users. As the tech industry continues to evolve, the role of generative AI models like DBRX in shaping future innovations remains a topic of ongoing discussion and exploration.

post_title: Everything you need to know about the Microsoft Exchange Server hack
post_content:
Update 26.3.2024: Following the large-scale Microsoft Exchange Server hack in 2021, security issues affecting Exchange Server have resurfaced. In the recent March 2024 monthly patch cycle, Microsoft addressed critical vulnerabilities in software such as HyperV and Exchange Server. These fixes come after the release of the 2024 H1 Cumulative Update for Exchange Server in February.

The 2024 H1 Cumulative Update introduces Extended Protection (EP) as a default feature. EP is designed to protect servers from man-in-the-middle (MiTM) attacks and was initially announced in 2023. This security enhancement aims to mitigate CVE-2024-21410, a privilege escalation vulnerability that can lead to NTLM relay attacks on Exchange Server. This particular vulnerability is actively exploited in the wild.

According to Microsoft, attackers could exploit an NTLM client like Outlook with a credentials-leaking vulnerability, allowing them to relay leaked credentials to the Exchange server to gain privileges and perform operations on behalf of the victim client. CVE-2024-21410 was disclosed in the February 2024 Microsoft patch update.

Original article from 2021:
Several zero-day vulnerabilities in Microsoft Exchange Server are currently being exploited by state-sponsored threat actors and other malicious entities to deploy backdoors and malware in widespread attacks. Although these incidents are not linked to the SolarWinds supply chain breach affecting thousands of organizations globally, there are concerns that delays in patching vulnerable servers could have severe repercussions for businesses.

Microsoft was alerted to four zero-day vulnerabilities in early January 2021, with reports suggesting that attacks leveraging these vulnerabilities began as early as January 6, 2021. The release of patches on March 2, 2021, aimed to address these critical vulnerabilities in Microsoft Exchange Server software. Despite the availability of fixes, the extent of potential Exchange Server compromises hinges on the prompt application of patches, and the security issue persists over a month later.

The vulnerabilities, collectively known as ProxyLogon, impact on-premise Exchange Server versions 2013, 2016, and 2019, while Exchange Online remains unaffected. Microsoft has also extended updates to Exchange Server 2010 for added security measures.

The specific vulnerabilities include CVE-2021-26855, a Server Side Request Forgery (SSRF) flaw; CVE-2021-26857, an insecure deserialization vulnerability in the Exchange Unified Messaging Service; CVE-2021-26858, an arbitrary file write vulnerability post-authentication; and CVE-2021-27065, another post-authentication arbitrary file write issue.

As the situation evolves, it is crucial for organizations using Microsoft Exchange Server to promptly apply patches and follow recommended security practices to mitigate the risks posed by these vulnerabilities. Stay informed and stay protected.

post_title: 5 simple things you should do to make MacOS more secure
post_content:
Jack Wallen/ZDNET

As a devoted Linux user, I've always prioritized security in my operating system. However, when I delved into using MacOS as my secondary OS, I quickly realized that a lax approach to security was not an option. While MacOS boasts a decent level of security, it's essential to take proactive steps to safeguard your data in a world where cyber threats are rampant.

To help you fortify your MacOS machine, I've curated a list of essential security measures that are easy to implement. Let's dive into the key steps to enhance the security of your iMac or MacBook.

1. Strengthen Your Passwords
The importance of strong passwords cannot be overstated. Whether it's for your applications, online accounts, or local user account on MacOS, ensure that you use robust and unique passwords. Avoid common choices like 'password' or '123456' – opt for complex combinations that are difficult to crack. Remember, a secure password is your first line of defense against malicious actors. Consider using a reliable password manager to store and manage your credentials securely.

2. Keep Your System Updated
Regularly checking for software updates is crucial for maintaining the security of your MacOS device. Enable automatic software updates to ensure that you stay protected against vulnerabilities. Security patches are often included in updates, so taking a few moments to check for and install updates can significantly enhance your device's security posture.

3. Activate the Firewall
Many users are unaware that the MacOS firewall is disabled by default. Enabling the firewall adds an extra layer of protection by blocking unauthorized network connections. This is particularly important when connecting to public Wi-Fi networks, such as those in coffee shops or businesses. To enable the MacOS firewall, navigate to System Preferences > Network > Firewall and toggle the On/Off switch to the 'On' position.

4. Disable Automatic Login
Auto-login may seem convenient, but it poses a security risk by granting easy access to your account. Disable automatic login in System Preferences > Users & Groups to prevent unauthorized users from gaining entry to your system. Note that auto login is not available when FileVault encryption is enabled.

5. Enable FileVault Encryption
FileVault is a powerful encryption tool built into MacOS that encrypts your entire disk, safeguarding your data from unauthorized access. To enable FileVault, go to System Preferences > Security & Privacy, select the FileVault tab, and click 'Turn On.' Ensure that your encryption key is securely stored in your iCloud account for recovery purposes.

By following these five simple yet effective security tips, you can enhance the protection of your MacOS machine and keep your sensitive data safe from prying eyes. Prioritizing security measures is essential in today's digital landscape to safeguard your privacy and maintain the integrity of your information.

post_title: Wase zaps microbes to squeeze more biogas from wastewater sludge
post_content:
Thomas Fudge, the founder of Wase, is revolutionizing the treatment of wastewater by turning sludge into a valuable resource. Rather than costly offsite treatment, Wase offers a sustainable solution that not only treats water on site but also generates free energy in the process.

Traditionally, companies have harvested methane from organic waste to reduce their carbon footprint and extract some value from the sludge. Wase's innovative approach involves building a smaller, more efficient system that utilizes electro-active microbes to maximize methane production. By providing a conducive environment for these bacteria to thrive on electrically charged electrodes, Wase's system can operate at lower temperatures and a wider range of conditions than conventional anaerobic digesters.

The key to Wase's success lies in its ability to optimize the growth and performance of these microbes in real-time. By monitoring current flow and implementing a control system, operators can ensure the bacteria are happy and productive, leading to more effective breakdown of organic compounds.

Recently securing an £8.5 million seed round, Wase is poised to implement its technology on a dairy farm in Wales and collaborate with breweries to further reduce the carbon footprint of wastewater treatment. While the methane produced by Wase's system will initially be burned on site, the potential for transporting biogas to the natural gas grid aligns with the EU's ambitious targets for biogas production by 2030.

In essence, Wase's innovative approach not only transforms wastewater treatment into a sustainable and energy-efficient process but also paves the way for a greener future in the biogas industry. post_title: Amazon fined in Poland for dark pattern design tricks
post_content:

Amazon has expressed its intention to appeal the fine, highlighting the need for transparency and clear communication in online sales practices. The company's response underscores the importance of providing consumers with accurate information and ensuring a fair shopping experience for all.

post_title: Taming the beast: Researcher controls voltage response for safer electric grid

His family's first connection to electric service came with a single portable light bulb, a mere 15 watts, attached to a cable. It was young Peng's responsibility to change the bulb when needed. Driven by this near-death encounter, Peng dedicated his life to understanding and controlling electricity. His latest research, recently published in Scientific Reports, introduces a groundbreaking semiconductor device known as a Z-source inverter. This innovative technology can swiftly reduce voltage and current during circuit faults, providing a level of protection unmatched by traditional safety mechanisms.

While conventional circuit breakers may take up to 50 milliseconds to activate in the event of a fault, Peng's digital Z-source inverter can respond in just 5 microseconds—a remarkable improvement in safety measures that could prevent fatalities and fires. By detecting and managing short circuits with unprecedented speed, this device offers a crucial layer of defense in our electrical systems.

In normal operation, electricity flows smoothly from generators to end users through power lines and cables. However, disruptions like short circuits or downed trees can lead to catastrophic consequences, including wildfires. Peng's electronic switch not only detects faults swiftly but also adapts to varying input voltages without additional components, enhancing its versatility and efficiency.

The potential applications of Peng's research extend beyond safety measures. By integrating renewable energy sources like wind turbines and photovoltaic cells into the power grid, we can better regulate voltage fluctuations and prevent power surges. Additionally, implementing advanced power electronics and control systems can enhance the stability and resilience of our electrical infrastructure.

As we confront the challenges posed by aging grids, cybersecurity threats, and environmental concerns, Peng's work offers a glimpse into the future of power technology. By harnessing the capabilities of power electronics, we have the opportunity to reshape our grids, enhance safety measures, and ensure a sustainable energy future.

A recent study conducted by Defiance Capital delves into the world of unicorn founders, uncovering some fascinating insights. Unicorns, referring to companies valued over a billion dollars, often have founders who can be considered "underdogs," with a rising number of female founders making their mark. The study focused on 845 unicorns and 2,018 founders from the U.S. and U.K. between 2013 and 2023, aiming to identify the common characteristics of these successful entrepreneurs.

Key Findings of the Study:

- 70% of unicorns have founders who are considered underdogs, such as immigrants, women, and people of color.
- The presence of female founders in unicorns has been on the rise, with 17% of unicorns in 2023 having a female founder.
- 53% of unicorn founders hold degrees from the top 10 global universities.
- STEM degrees are prevalent among unicorn CEOs, with 49% holding STEM degrees, and an even higher percentage among female founding CEOs.
- The market for potential unicorn investments is fragmented at the seed stage, with only a few VC funds having a significant presence.

The study also highlighted the diversity among unicorn founders, with a significant number of Asian and non-white founders contributing to the unicorn landscape. Interestingly, the study found that teams with female founders tend to be younger when founding their unicorns compared to all-male teams.

Traits of Unicorn Founders:

The study identified three key factors that define the "DNA" of a unicorn founder:
1. No "plan B"
2. A chip on the shoulder
3. Unlimited self-belief

Unicorn founders often exhibit a growth mindset, with values and ambitions shaped during their formative years. Many founders have personal stories of overcoming challenges and limitations in their native environments, leading them to become ambitious rebels driven by a greater cause.

Implications for VCs:

The study's findings challenge traditional notions of what makes a successful founder. While certain stereotypes, such as Ivy League graduates with traditional backgrounds, do exist among unicorn founders, they are not as prevalent as one might assume. VCs may need to reassess their investment strategies to capitalize on the diverse pool of talent in the unicorn space.

In conclusion, the study sheds light on the unique characteristics of unicorn founders, highlighting the importance of resilience, self-belief, and a drive to succeed against all odds. As the unicorn landscape continues to evolve, embracing diversity and unconventional backgrounds may be the key to unlocking future success in the startup world.

post_title: New password reset attack targets Apple device users - what to do if it happens to you

This malicious scheme aims to steal user data by exploiting Apple's password reset feature. Reports have surfaced of scammers bombarding targets with numerous notifications prompting them to reset their Apple ID password. Choosing the "Allow" option could potentially grant scammers access to reset the user's credentials, leading to a breach of their account security.

Subsequently, victims of this scam have reported receiving phone calls from individuals claiming to be Apple support representatives. These scammers attempt to extract a password reset code from the user, enabling them to reset the Apple ID password and gain unauthorized access to the account. The deceptive tactics employed in this phishing attack highlight the importance of remaining vigilant and cautious when handling unexpected password reset requests.

Recent statistics reveal a significant increase in mobile phishing attacks, with a staggering 61% rise in 2022 alone. This alarming trend underscores the need for enhanced security measures and user awareness to mitigate the risks associated with such fraudulent activities.

The widespread nature of the MFA bombing attack targeting Apple users underscores the urgency for proactive security measures. While there is no foolproof solution to prevent such attacks, users are advised to exercise caution and refrain from engaging with suspicious requests. Choosing the "Don't Allow" option on unauthorized password reset notifications is crucial in thwarting potential phishing attempts and safeguarding personal information.

In light of these security concerns, it is essential for Apple users to remain vigilant and informed about potential threats. Being aware of common phishing tactics and maintaining a skeptical attitude towards unsolicited communications can help mitigate the risks of falling victim to fraudulent schemes. Remember, Apple does not initiate direct calls to users, and any unexpected communication should be treated with caution to prevent unauthorized access to personal data.

As the cybersecurity landscape continues to evolve, staying informed and proactive in safeguarding personal information is paramount. post_title: Novel multifunctional additive boosts efficiency, stability of inverted perovskite solar cells
post_content:
Prof. Ge Ziyi's team at the Ningbo Institute of Materials Technology and Engineering (NIMTE) of the Chinese Academy of Sciences has made significant strides in the development of inverted perovskite solar cells (PSCs) by introducing a novel multifunctional additive to enhance efficiency and stability.

Perovskite solar cells have emerged as a promising technology in the realm of photovoltaics due to their remarkable optoelectronic properties and cost-effectiveness. However, challenges such as low power conversion efficiency and poor long-term stability have hindered their widespread adoption. These issues are often linked to defects in the perovskite films and voltage losses in the devices.

To tackle these challenges, the researchers at NIMTE incorporated potassium (4-tert-butoxycarbonylpiperazin-1-yl) methyl trifluoroborate (PTFBK) into the perovskite precursor solution. This additive played a crucial role in passivating defects and enhancing carrier transport within the perovskite films. The synergistic effects of PTFBK led to improved crystallization and the formation of high-quality perovskite films with larger grain sizes.

As a result of these advancements, the team achieved impressive power conversion efficiencies of 24.99% and 23.48% for rigid and flexible inverted PSCs, respectively. Furthermore, the modified devices exhibited exceptional stability under various environmental conditions, including high temperatures, humidity, and continuous illumination.

Notably, the flexible PSCs demonstrated remarkable bending stability, retaining 85% of their initial efficiency after 5,000 bending cycles. These findings mark a significant step forward in the development and potential commercialization of perovskite solar cells and related photovoltaic technologies.

The study, published in Angewandte Chemie International Edition, showcases the promising future of inverted PSCs and sets the stage for further advancements in the field of renewable energy.

post_title: 6 ways to protect yourself from getting scammed online, by phone, or IRL
post_content:
I recently witnessed a friend fall victim to a scam that almost resulted in his credit card information being stolen. It made me realize how prevalent scams are and how important it is to stay vigilant. Scammers are constantly evolving, making it crucial for us to be aware of their tactics.

Here are some tips to help you avoid falling prey to scams:

1. Be suspicious of emails and messages. If you don't know the sender or can't verify their identity, delete and block the message. Avoid clicking on links in emails unless you can confirm they are from a legitimate source.

2. Check links before clicking on them. Scammers often use fake links to trick you into giving away personal information. Always verify the legitimacy of a link before clicking on it.

3. If an offer sounds too good to be true, it probably is. Scammers prey on our vulnerabilities, so be cautious of any unsolicited offers, especially those related to money or technology issues.

4. Know how organizations contact you. The IRS, for example, will only contact you via mail, not email or phone calls. Be wary of anyone claiming to be from a government agency or reputable company if they don't use official channels of communication.

5. Let unknown phone calls go. If you receive a call from an unfamiliar number, it's best to ignore it. Scammers often use phone calls to trick people into giving away personal information.

By staying vigilant and following these tips, you can protect yourself from falling victim to scams. Remember, awareness is the best defense against scammers.

post_title: Rabbit partners with ElevenLabs to power voice commands on its device
post_content:
Hardware manufacturer Rabbit has announced a collaboration with ElevenLabs to integrate voice commands into its upcoming r1 devices. Following a successful debut at CES earlier this year, Rabbit is gearing up to release the first batch of r1 devices next month.

The Rabbit r1 will come equipped with ElevenLabs' technology, allowing users to interact with the device using voice commands and receive responses from a pocket AI assistant. Initially, the voice command feature will be available only in English with a single voice option. ElevenLabs emphasizes that their low latency models will enhance the naturalness of interactions with the device.

ElevenLabs' CEO, Mati Staniszewski, expressed excitement about the partnership with Rabbit, stating, "We're collaborating with Rabbit to revolutionize human-device interaction. Our goal is to make the r1 a truly dynamic co-pilot."

In addition to voice commands, Rabbit has also announced a partnership with Perplexity AI to provide users with answers to their queries on the device. The first wave of $199 r1 devices is expected to ship by the end of March, with features such as chatbot interaction, bi-directional translation, ride and food ordering, and music playback right out of the box.

CEO of Rabbit, Jesse Lyu, revealed at a recent event that the company has already received close to 100,000 device orders, indicating strong demand for their innovative products.

Meanwhile, ElevenLabs recently secured $80 million in Series B funding, propelling the company towards unicorn status. Specializing in voice cloning services for various applications such as audiobooks, dubbing, and character voices, ElevenLabs has garnered attention from platforms like PocketFM in India.

Despite its success, ElevenLabs has faced criticism for potential misuse of its technology, including attempts to bypass bank authentication systems and create fake celebrity voices. To address these concerns, the startup has developed tools to detect and prevent the misuse of synthesized audio.

Overall, the collaboration between Rabbit and ElevenLabs signals a new era of interactive and intuitive technology, promising exciting possibilities for users seeking seamless voice-controlled experiences.

post_title: This camera captures 156.3 trillion frames per second
post_content:
Scientists have developed an ultrafast scientific camera called SCARF (swept-coded aperture real-time femtophotography) that can capture images at an encoding rate of 156.3 terahertz (THz) per individual pixel, equivalent to a staggering 156.3 trillion frames per second. This cutting-edge camera has the potential to revolutionize the study of micro-events that occur too rapidly for current high-end scientific sensors to capture.

SCARF has already demonstrated its capabilities by successfully recording ultrafast phenomena such as absorption in semiconductors and the demagnetization of metal alloys. This breakthrough research opens up new possibilities in various fields, including shock wave mechanics and the development of more efficient medical treatments.

The driving force behind this innovative camera is Professor Jinyang Liang from Canada's Institut national de la recherche scientifique (INRS), a renowned expert in the field of ultrafast photography. Building on his previous groundbreaking work, Professor Liang and his team published their latest research in Nature, as reported by Science Daily and summarized in a press release from INRS.

Unlike traditional ultrafast cameras that capture frames sequentially and then piece them together, SCARF takes a fresh approach. By utilizing a unique imaging modality that enables ultrafast sweeping of a static coded aperture without distorting the phenomenon, this camera achieves encoding rates of up to 156.3 THz per pixel in a single shot. This revolutionary technique allows for the observation of rapid events in both reflection and transmission modes with tunable frame rates and spatial scales.

In simple terms, SCARF employs computational imaging to capture spatial information by allowing light to enter its sensor at different times. By processing the raw data using a computer algorithm, the camera can decode the time-staggered inputs and reconstruct trillions of frames into a coherent image. What sets SCARF apart is its use of off-the-shelf optical components, making it a cost-effective, low-power solution with high measurement quality compared to existing methods.

While SCARF is primarily geared towards research applications, collaborations with companies like Axis Photonique and Few-Cycle indicate potential commercial development for wider use in academic and scientific settings. For a more detailed understanding of the camera and its implications, the full paper in Nature provides further technical insights.

In conclusion, SCARF represents a significant advancement in ultrafast imaging technology, offering unprecedented capabilities for studying rapid events with remarkable precision and efficiency. This groundbreaking camera has the potential to drive innovation across various scientific disciplines and pave the way for exciting discoveries in the future.

post_title: This new AI tool from Adobe makes generating the images you need even simpler
post_content:
The rise of generative artificial intelligence (AI) has revolutionized the way we create images from simple text inputs. Tech giants like Adobe are constantly enhancing user experiences, with the latest update to Adobe Firefly showcasing the new Structure Reference feature.

During the recent Adobe Summit, Structure Reference was introduced as a powerful tool within Adobe Firefly, allowing users to input an image as a template for the AI model to generate a new image with similar layout and composition. This feature gives users unprecedented control over the output of generated images, enabling them to fine-tune the "strength" of the structure reference to tailor the image creation process to their specific needs.

In a live demo at the event, a user uploaded a profile image as a structure reference, prompting Firefly to produce multiple new images that retained the structure of the original photo. By adjusting the strength of the reference, users can dictate how closely the generated image adheres to the original template, offering a spectrum of creative possibilities.

Moreover, Structure Reference works seamlessly alongside Style Reference, which uses an image as a reference to generate a new image in the same style, including color schemes and overall aesthetic. By leveraging both features and detailed prompts, users can ensure that the images generated meet their requirements on the first attempt, eliminating the need for multiple iterations and refining.

Deepa Subramaniam, Adobe's VP of product marketing, highlighted the transformative nature of these features, likening it to a shift from 2D to 3D in the creative process. The ability to use images as guidelines opens up new avenues for creativity, allowing users to visually communicate their ideas without the constraints of traditional prompts.

With Structure Reference now available on both web and mobile platforms, users can experiment with this innovative tool by visiting the Adobe Firefly website. This new feature represents a significant leap forward in the realm of generative AI, empowering users to bring their creative visions to life with ease and precision.
